titlepage.titleproper: A Guide to the United Way of Greater Richmond /Richmond Community Fund records 1911-1987
titlepage.subtitle:

archdesc.runner: Special Collections and Archives, James Branch Cabell Library, Virginia Commonwealth University

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.repository: Special Collections and Archives, James Branch Cabell Library, Virginia Commonwealth University
did.unittitle:
United Way of Greater Richmond /Richmond Community records
1911-1987

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for use without restrictions.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Box/Folder, M 247 United Way of Greater Richmond/Richmond Community Fund records, Special Collections and Archives, James Branch Cabell Library, Virginia Commonwealth University, Richmond, VA.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Donated to the Department by William F. Wright of the United Way in 1987.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collection processed in October 1987, revised in February 1989, June 1989, March 2000, and June 2002.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Information
bioghist.p: The Richmond Area Community Council began in 1911. In 1924 it created the Community Fund, a community-wide trust, to consolidate the fund-raising efforts of area charitable organizations, like the YWCA and Associated Charities (later the Family Service Society). During World War II, the Community Fund became the Richmond War and Community Fund, and after the war the Richmond Community Chest.
In 1974, the Richmond Area Community Council announced the merger of the Council with the United Way.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of correspondence, meeting minutes, budgets, committee files, newsletters, and various other materials related to the operation of this organization. In addition, scrapbooks reveal the activities of the organization, and photographs of past presidents of the Richmond Community Council.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The materials are arranged alphabetically by subject, then arranged chronologiaclly where applicable. The oversized scrapbooks are numbered separately.
